Review Text: Thought we would give the zoo a try. About £10 per person for tourists which was ok. Quite an easy route to follow around . A reasonable array of animals but can’t say I felt comfortable seeing some of them in small areas for their size, eg Tigers, bears . Keepers made a point of letting tourists feed animals , nice touch. Lots of signs saying don’t throw rubbish! Waste of time given the amount rubbish we saw all over and in enclosures. Overall we found it pretty grubby and far too cramped for a good few animals of the larger variety. A very run down zoo.

Our Trip to the Zoo was great, the Uber was able to drop us off directly infront of the main entrance of the zoo, I will caution it is a busy tight street with no sidewalks so if you are bringing your children,  be mindful of the vehicles. There are 3 different prices, Local, Tourist, and another that was less than Tourist but more than Visitor. If you have a Diplomatic ID you will get the local price which is 200LKR vs. The 4000LKR tourist price. The entrance line was hectic, and you had to stand your ground when people tried to cut, but it was very quick to get through (we went around 3 hrs before closing) As we walked around the animals were actually out and present which is a nice change from past experiences at other zoos. A Zoo employee offered us a guided tour, moving us around crowds providing us front views of the animals, and carried snacks and plants that he handed us to feed the animals. There was no agreed upon price for this tour, at the end it was simply put "if you were happy with your experience please tip what youd like" During the walk around another employer added himself onto our tour and also asked for tip, I tipped him less because I knew what the deal was but wanted to be appreciative of the assistance.  Although I am sure we were targeted for this guided tour because we were American, it honestly made my kids day and felt like VIP treatment, so I did not mind at all. We were able to get up close and Personal with both the Elephants and thw Giraffes and feed and touch them both. So I actually recommend the tour. It was hot so I suggest bringing water and a fan. But there are refreshment vendors on the path.

Review Title: Zoo considers tourists not has human beings but as money bags
Review Text: Well I can not recommend this place, because of very high entrance rates for foreigners ! Again and again it shows how Sri Lanka despises tourists in their country. Rates for tourist are nearly 20 x higher than for local people , please never go there ! Prejudice and economic racisme is rampant in that country !

Had a wonderful time at Dehiwala Zoo! The variety of animals was impressive, and the grounds were clean and well-maintained. It’s a peaceful place to walk around and a great spot for families and kids. The animal enclosures are spacious, and the staff were friendly and helpful. The aquarium and reptile sections were especially interesting. Highly recommended for a fun and educational outing near Colombo!

Review Title: A great place to spend time in the wild.
Review Text: The Dehiwela Zoo is a fantastic day out for all ages!  I was impressed by the spacious enclosures and the obvious care taken with the animals.  The variety of species is remarkable, from majestic elephants to playful primates.  The bird show was a highlight, showcasing vibrant colours and impressive skills.  The zoo's layout is easy to navigate, and there are plenty of food stalls and rest areas.  A truly enjoyable and educational experience, I highly recommend a visit to the Dehiwela Zoo!

Review Title: Best place to watch animals in a zoo
Review Text: Well experienced place to watch animals in a zoo and got lot of knowledge about animal world. Recommended for children to come and visit.
Good few hours with family. Fed elephants there and went to eat delicious vag food at the end. Good experience overall..

This zoo should be closed. Terrible conditions for the animals. Small cages, distressed animals and some had no shadows for the sun. Please, dont contribute to keep this place open. They charge a lot more for foreigners than locals, but it does not justify the horrible life of the animals.

Review Title: A Fun-Filled Family Adventure at Dehiwala Zoo
Review Text: The zoo is home to a wide variety of animals, from majestic elephants to playful monkeys and colorful birds. The enclosures are well-maintained, and the animals appear healthy and well-cared for. One of the highlights was the elephant show, where we got to see these gentle giants up close, showcasing their intelligence and strength. The zoo also has a beautiful butterfly garden that was a peaceful retreat amid the excitement of the day. The staff were friendly and knowledgeable, always ready to answer questions and provide interesting facts about the animals. It’s clear they care deeply about conservation and educating the public. While the zoo can get busy, especially on weekends, there are plenty of shaded areas to relax and enjoy a picnic. The kids particularly loved the reptile house and the chance to feed some of the animals. Overall, Dehiwala Zoo offers a fun and educational experience for families and animal lovers alike. It's a great way to spend a day, especially if you're looking to learn more about wildlife in Sri Lanka. Highly recommend a visit if you're in the Colombo area! #ExploreSriLanka #ScenicLankaPersonalTourDrivers
We went dahiwala zoo it was nice place varites of animals .i love elephant dance they have train so well but some of spaces are small to them but we watch and enjoy good place for kids to visit

I am very happy with the day that was spent. It is very valuable to have information boards displayed everywhere. I went here for the first time.. Some of the animals seemed to be sick. Very sad to see them. The bird park is very beautiful. There are many things to learn about animals. You can also learn about trees.

All animals look sad and depressed . The upkeep of the snakes and the bear is extremely saddening . The tigers look disoriented. The space allotted for these majestic creatures is really small. In my opinion all zoos should be shut no matter where they are . The poor animals do not deserve a life of this sort . My advise to tourists pls do not go to any zoo..

The humid Sri Lankan air clung to me as I entered the Dehiwela Zoo. As a traveler with a penchant for wildlife, this was a must-visit on my Sri Lankan itinerary. Stepping through the gates, the cacophony of animal calls replaced the city's honking symphony. My first stop was the elephant enclosure. These gentle giants, Sri Lanka's national treasure, were munching on hay. A sense of awe washed over me as I observed their wrinkled grey skin and intelligent eyes.  A young elephant playfully sprayed itself with water from its trunk, a gesture that made me chuckle. Next, the playful chatter of monkeys drew me in. The Sri Lanka Langurs, with their distinctive black faces, swung from branch to branch, seemingly unfazed by the watching crowd.  A troop of macaques squabbled over a fallen banana, their antics providing a moment of amusement. The roar of a lion echoed through the zoo, sending shivers down my spine.  Approaching the lion enclosure with a mix of anticipation and trepidation, I saw the majestic creature lounging in the shade. Its golden mane shimmered in the sunlight, and its powerful presence commanded respect. The Dehiwela Zoo isn't just about the big cats. I wandered past enclosures housing a variety of fascinating creatures, each with its own unique story.  The graceful peacocks strutted their vibrant feathers, the zebras grazed peacefully, and the giraffes stretched their long necks, offering a glimpse into their leafy breakfast. One of the highlights was the feeding time at the hippopotamus enclosure. These enormous creatures lumbered out of the water, eagerly awaiting their meal.  It was a sight that both impressed and slightly terrified me with their sheer size and powerful jaws.

There are plenty of animals to see but sadly not in very good surroundings,just not enough space for the birds to fly and the large animals to move naturally…very sad.The cost of a ticket for a foreign adult was 17 us dollars.There are a couple of food vendors and a main indoor dining room…we spent around 2 hours there but could have done it quicker.

This was one of the most horrendous animal experiences I’ve ever encountered. We went with family, who had in turn gone as children to this zoo - so it was a trip down memory lane for them. I was hoping there would be some element of care for the animals - after all, they advertise that you can see elephants, lions, bears, giraffes and more. I was incredibly shocked by what we saw. On arrival we learnt about the “World Children’s Day” event where staff proudly told us school kids are allowed to pet the lion cubs. I was shocked that anyone is allowed to handle the cubs - and can only image what is done to control the cubs in these circumstances (drugging, starvation, lack of water - all to control behaviour). Elephants are chained and poked into submission using ‘phaajaan’ and then made to parade, perform and “dance” - a tradition at this zoo dating back decades apparently. It’s disgusting to watch - much like the old circus activities that are Elephants balance on each other and form shapes. I was shocked at how many local people come here to cheer and champion this treatment, without any care for the treatment of the animals. I would have thought people are more educated about this in 2024 and should know how cruel this is! The worst thing was that there is no acknowledgement of how wrong it is to treat any animals this way. They are blatantly tortured and exploited for human entertainment - and tamed into submission in ways we all know are cruel. Yet people pay to see this. While this might be down to a lack of local education, I suspect that’s not the case in this day and age - rather that, at Dehiwala Zoo, making money is far more important than animal welfare. This zoo should be shut down, and I hope other travellers can help share this message so people do not spend their money here in future.

Well I can not recommend this place, because of very high entrance rates for foreigners ! Again and again it shows how Sri Lanka despises tourists in their country. Rates for tourist are nearly 20 x higher than for local people , please never go there ! Prejudice and economic racisme is rampant in that country !

I visited this zoo 5 years ago (visited before too being Sri Lankan born) and had a good experience as it had just been renovated. This visit today was a total disappointment. So sad to see the neglect of the zoo compared to 5 years ago. Sri Lanka sadly has a bad record of maintaining anything new which belongs to the government, they run it down as seen even on the first class carriages of the trains! Animals were suffering, not given adequate facilities to suit their living environment. Lack of water for water bathing animals such as elephants, hypo’s, bears etc. animal cruelty is at its best at this zoo, will never go there again on my future visits to the country!
This is my second time they have improved a lot.. Kids had a great time .will visit again for sure.. Better to i the morning ..

Since I visited the zoo on a day off, which also coincided with the day of the full moon, then, as you may have guessed, there were a countless number of people at the ticket office. But, lo and behold, a local woman came up and took me to the cash register. It turned out that “whites” were allowed in without a queue. The ticket price at that time (January 2023) was 3000 rupees. Now the price on the official website is $15. But payment is accepted only in local currency. Established in 1936, Dehiwala Zoo is one of the oldest zoos in Asia. It is located in the suburbs, just a few minutes' drive from the center of Colombo. The zoo is home to more than 300 different species of animals, birds, reptiles and fish from around the world. The animals live in large enclosures and are well cared for. The animals look healthy. I really liked the park's navigation. If you follow the signs, you will definitely not miss anything. And the territory of the zoo is not small. In addition to the main enclosures, there is a reptile corner, an aquarium, a “Bird House” and a “Butterfly Garden”. Unfortunately, the Butterfly Garden was not open on the day of my visit. All cages have a small sign with detailed information about the animal being kept in the cage, making a visit to the zoo very educational. Also at certain times (it is indicated on the back of the tickets) feeding of different animals takes place. For an additional fee, you can feed giraffes, pelicans, parrots and other birds yourself. And in a special arena with an amphitheater you can see the “Elephant Show”. I didn’t make it to the beginning because I didn’t calculate the time and was delayed at the other end of the zoo. Don't make the same mistakes I did if you want to watch the whole show. ) If you get hungry during or after your walk, at the entrance you will find sellers of street food and cotton candy. There are several kiosks throughout the zoo where you can buy drinks and snacks. There are many benches and gazebos in the park where you can sit down to rest, have a snack or hide from the rain. It is better to visit on weekdays when there are fewer people.

Wonderful experience walking around the zoo, we didn't expect it to be big, but it turned out to be huge! You can easily spend up to 5 or 6 hours here! Saw a few animals that I wasn't expecting to see here, but it was a pleasant surprise.

I first visited the zoo about thirty five years ago when the only thing I enjoyed was the flora. The animals at that time were poorly housed with very poor attention to the weather of some of the larger mammals. On my visit in March 2023 this was no longer the case . The animals looked well cared for and the visit was an enjoyable experience . I feel that the zoo now has an important function in educating and encouraging future generations to look after habitats in our own environments. The flora was once more a joy to behold.
One of the nice places to visit in Sri Lanka. Specially with kids. It takes avg. 4 hrs to visit whole animals inside the zoo.
I have visited this place many times. Its very encouraging to see more space allocated for the animals. Definitely a place to visit.
This is definitely a place to visit in Sri Lanka. Glad to see the authorities giving more space for the animals.

This was my 8th time during last 50 years!  Lot improved so far.  but less animals and more people  Some new cages are getting ready.  I usually go with tourists and their rates are up now, way up.  Reasonable for locals.  In the middle of city you can relax, enjoy the shady garden and watch animals from all around the world.  The big disappointment is main restaurant does not serve rice and curry, only foreign food for visiting locals!  This should be a good place to promote, introduce Sri Lankan food not chinsed food!!  Another place has rice and curry, but very limited, and we waited in the line for a long time that guy served others with take away and ignored us, so we left!  That place was not so clean, broken furniture, dirty floor, left over food on the tables, not even good for the locals, mainly for Zoo workers.

National Zoological Gardens of Sri Lanka is a zoological garden in Dehiwala, Sri Lanka, founded in 1936. Its sprawling areas are host to a variety of animals and birds. The zoo exhibits animals but also places an emphasis on animal conservation and welfare, and education.

It’s been 3 years since the last time I visited the Dehiwala Zoo and it was me and husband only when we are still a couple. Before it was too crowded when this covid-19 didn’t hit the country. Me and my family especially my 2 yr. old daughter enjoyed the sightseeing of each animals. I loved how they added some attractions like the museum, butterfly farm and the birds cage place. Since it’s the biggest zoo in Sri Lanka, it will take you sometime to see all the animals and you should ready your hat, water everything that can cover you up since it’s a very long walk. I hope that they maintain the place how it is where the animals will feel comfortable and especially continue to take care of the them(animals). Overall, we enjoyed the walk just a little smell is there but it’s kinda normal since it’s a zoo and it’s full of animals.
Large zoo, very cheap entrance and cheap snacks and ice cream stalls in abundance. So many animals to see for little ones including komodo dragon. Lovely playground inside.

Great place to spend the day with young kids and nature enthusiastic teens Very large area to cover so get ready to walk.. they have buggies (at a fee) for those who cannot walk much Weekends can be crowded with locals Make sure you have a cap and sunglasses And hand sanitizer .. you can touch some smaller animals The place is clean .. does not smell bad Many food outlets inside If your there on a Sunday make sure you watch the elephant show The open birds atrium is amazing.. The negatives are just outside the entrance.. watch out for hawkers Do not take tuktuks (expensive) from the entrance better to install pickme app and order cabs online

Lovely place to spend a morning there, watching animal eating in the morning time. It is very nice that to same animals you can get really close. There are a small aquarium, a reptile ace, a butterfly place. It is very nice.

Its one of the largest zoo's i have seen in Srilanka. It has the name boards around 45 locations inside the zoo were the animals are kept. It has a separate parking for the vehicles. It has an restaurant and few eatery options in between the pathway. Owl's is one of the top attractions found specially in Srilanka. It takes around minimum 3-4 hours to cover up the entire park and will be good fun ride for the kids.
Nice experience for us. My son was very happy with the garden and the animals. Its the first experience for him

Not the best experience. Animals seemed to be well maintained. Layout was a bit confusing. The butterfly garden was very limited and not as advertised. Foreigners are overcharged at the entrance (Lkr 3000) for adult. Detailed Information was provided for some of the animals.

Sri Lanka national zoological garden is a famous attractive place In Colombo.it is good place to visit with friends and family.also with new development in zoo park there are so many new things and pieces added. Best time to travel in early in the morning or evening. Weekend night life educational journey also happening.
As a family we visited the National Zoological Gardens of Sri Lanka and enjoyed the new setting very much as it gives much freedom to the animals and better experience to the visitors.

Buddus are the beings who are bellow intellect. Animals, Birds, Reptiles, Fish are some of them. Buddus is a Sanskrit language name. Some of our human beings are also having Animal qualities. You can meet all of them here. It is the Zoo in Dehiwala town in Colombo, Sri Lanka

I have been there so many times. the renovations are almost done. good to see the animals are well looked after now. the new entrance and the new bird area is fantastic. hope the people will take care of the place. need more animals .
Can get crowded in weekends, public holidays and school vacation. Best to visit on a weekday. A rare collection of endemic birds and mammals.

Can’t believe people from the affluent wealthy West complain about paying higher admission fees than local residents! It’s worth the admission tommeander gently through this wonderfully maintained and extensive site. Green, luscious and full with  wonderfull trees of great  age and beauty, cafes and refreshments available - or take a picnic. Two,or three hours of sheer delight and wonder.
Best place in Colombo. Nice place. Family entertaining place. Children's enjoy place. 60 Type of animals including this zoology garden. Just only entry ticket 20/= (srilanka people)

This is my 3rd trip in 8 years and the last trip in September 2018 was very good. Earlier 2 visits the zoo was pretty smelly and unclean most of the areas. But they have fully refurbished the attractions with many improvements such as night safari, glass walls in some enclosures, new open elephant enclosure where elephants are free to walk, new animals such as hippos, helpful route maps, feeding animals etc. definitely suggest to take the night safari which had to pay extra for the buggy ride but fair charge.

A great range of birds, animals, reptiles. In good clean grounds. A long walk if you see everything. Would of got 5 stars except for the expensive entry fee , 2500 rupees for non Sri Lankans (only 100 rupees for locals).

This Zoo was the biggest in Asia and now part of it has been shifted to Pinnawala as an open zoo. Those days we had seals penguins etc but now not so wide a variety but still a large aquarium, butterfly garden, snake garden etc and many species of wild life from around the orld.

Visited the zoo by night, was quite nice and really enjoyed the tiger and lion exhibition. We also were able to travel around through a buggy cart with a guide which was very informative. Its great to see that they promote the nocturnal animals as well while not disturbing the rest.
A nice place to spend the day. The animals are beautiful. I love the exotic birds on the trees.and I always wait for the elephant dane. make sue you check the times.
I highly recommend that all tourists in Colombo should visit this Zoo. It needs 2.5 - 5 Hours to go thru the whole zoo.
